ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Professor is very responsive.The final negotiation was quite fun.
N/A

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course helps students to think environmental problems systematically.
Well-organized and detailed. Covers a lot of material but in a nice and systematic way. Gain some practical skills (excel, data mining).
Exercises were helpful. Lectures were interesting, if not always on target. Professor Oliver has a wealth of experience.

No other course takes as comprehensive and integrated a view of such a wide range of natural resources. Covers a great breadth of material and so provides a good introductory overview of many topics, some of which will be familiar but some of which will not.
I appreciate how the distribution of resources was presented, including the knowledge of the differences in topography and soil contributed to what agricultural products are grown, if any.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: N/A

Professor Oliver tends to ramble a bit in his lectures. I think there also lacks a central theme that pulls the course together. Often, it felt like an overview of ecology, geology, and ecological anthropology. I wish each lecture tied into a greater unified theme.

Greater emphasis on integrating the knowledge and information covered in the course, as opposed to simply presenting the information, would be helpful. This was the instructor's intention but the pacing of the course prevented going into much depth; future structural changes may rectify it.Also, some facts/definitions/concepts used are slightly out of date.

The assignments essentially involved data mining that took more time than actually answering the questions in the assignments themselves. While I appreciate the understanding of Professor Oliver in giving more leeway in answering the questions, I feel that more clarity in how the we were suppose to answer the questions will have helped and how much data mining was really necessary in coming up with the answers he wanted.Also, I feel that the instructions for the last class exercise on trading could have been improved and better given. Until the day when we held the exercise, I believe majority, if not everyone, in class were unsure of how we were suppose to go about it despite time spent in class presenting aspects of the exercise beforehand.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
There was no discussion/lab section for this course. We totally depended on the course lectures given by Professor Oliver.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The course provided clear overview of resources and environmental issues in global scale.
Helped me get a good understanding of the overall natural resources. Broad range of topics but detailed enough to allow you to discuss and anazyled data and reports.
This course was helpful to give me an overview of natural resources. Though not directly related to my field of study, it's information I feel I need to be an effective environmental manager.
My interests are in integrated, systemic, global-scale problems. An overview of the global natural resource base is therefore a necessary and foundational piece of knowledge for my purposes.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To better understand natural resources management. To learn more about the resources.
Fit my schedule and seemed interesting.
To learn more about the magnitudes and geographic distributions of various natural resources, how they are used, and how they are interdependent.

I took the course because I felt it would be relevant knowledge to have an appreciation of the distribution of resources, the differences in topography and other features, natural calamities and disasters affecting different regions of the world, and how all of these affected or influenced one another and how all of these contributed toworld trade.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: YES
Yes

Yes, though I would have preferred more clearly understandable spreadsheet work. Professor Oliver's spreadsheets are so confusing that he ends up having to go over them with us in class. I think it would benefit future classes for him to more clearly articulate our assignments so that we have sufficient information to figure them out on our own.
Somewhat. Breadth of knowledge was satisfactory, though mastery or grasp of that knowledge less so.

I did not have clear expectations from the course except to have an appreciation of the distribution of resources around the world and the other relevant aspects that affect and govern this resource distribution.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Working with group improved efficiency.Students can share different opinions with others.
Had good experience. Worked with a nice and helpful girl. Assignments were sometimes too complicated and we had to spend a lot of time understanding them.
Workload of groupwork not actually much lighter than simply doing work individually.

The amount of data mining affected the amount of time that we could've spent discussing in more detail the answers that we had to the questions in the exercises. As a result of the number and the broadness of questions for each assignment, we decided that we would divide the work as a group. While division of labor is practical, I feel very strongly that the degree of detail that was needed in cleaning up and truly appreciating the contents of the different sheets that contained the tables tended to distract from truly appreciating the responses to the questions.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's a good overview. Helpful class. Great professor.
If you don't have a background in environmental sciences, this course could be valuable. If you're taking the fundamentals Ecology course, you probably don't also need this one.

Do not be afraid to give Chad feedback or ask for what you want. The course may not seem like much as it is, but Chad is very responsive and open to modifying it to suit your needs and desires, so take advantage of that.

The lectures were very informative but basic. I feel strongly that this could pass or serve as a foundations course that would be very useful for all MEMs. I would advice a student who plans to take this course to fully ask the questions that would provide the information he or she needs from Professor Oliver.
